body_html: Hm, yeah, good point. Zenodo uses versioned DOIs by default, but mints an overarching one as well. I guess, it's optimised for the librarian's point of view of preserving what exactly was cited and the academic's PoV of specifying which version they used. I'm not sure whether they aggregate the citation data again for a record, which is cited by different people at different "points" of the "version history", so to speak.

I guess, it's optimised for the librarian's point of view of preserving what exactly was cited and the academic's PoV of specifying which version they used. body: Hm, yeah, good point. Zenodo [uses versioned DOIs by default, but mints an overarching one](https://help.zenodo.org/#versioning) as well. I guess, it's optimised for the librarian's point of view of preserving what exactly was cited and the academic's PoV of specifying which version they used. I'm not sure whether they aggregate the citation data again for a record, which is cited by different people at different "points" of the "version history", so to speak.
